awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE-IT Catalyst: Supporting the Success of a Diverse STEM Faculty at Brooklyn College
awd_abstract_narration:
Brooklyn College of the City University of New York will implement an ADVANCE Catalyst project to conduct an institutional self-assessment to understand the status of women faculty in STEM disciplines on the main campus. This project will include the collection and analysis of STEM faculty data to uncover the systemic gender-based inequities that exist at the institution.  The project will focus on individuals from underrepresented groups, including women, those from racial/ethnic groups under-represented in STEM areas, and individuals with non-binary gender identities. The project will add 10 years of historical data on all faculty to an existing academic data warehouse including information on salaries, rank at hiring, tenure decisions, history of progression in rank, and work factors such as start-up funding, laboratory resources (space, renovation), and workload flexibility for family needs. The data in the warehouse will be used to determine how the target groups have fared historically in STEM and will be the key resource for assessing equity needs and will provide a long-term data collection system for monitoring the impact of the ADVANCE project as well as other faculty focused efforts. This two-year project will prepare the university for future data collection and data analyses of faculty equity which can be used by institutional leadership to inform decision-making.  The Catalyst work will also prepare the institution to implement evidence-based strategies to enhance the university climate for all faculty which will be outlined in a five-year faculty equity strategic plan that will be produced as part of this project.   

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Catalyst" awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Objectives
This ADVANCE Catalyst project was undertaken to conduct an institutional self-assessment to reveal systemic identity-based inequities that exist for STEM faculty at Brooklyn College. The project focused on individuals from underrepresented groups including women, those from racial/ethnic groups underrepresented in STEM, and gender diverse individuals. We set out to compile a data warehouse that included information on salary, age and rank at hiring, tenure and promotion decisions, time between rank changes, and additional factors to uncover how focal groups have fared historically in STEM. We also set out to assess the impact of differential service contributions on professional advancement; to improve mentoring for faculty based on input from junior faculty about unmet needs; and to develop a five-year strategic STEM equity plan for recommendation to the College leadership.

Outcomes
The project produced meaningful outcomes consistent with our objectives. We gathered data from disparate Brooklyn College and CUNY databases to build a data warehouse that allowed us to uncover identity-based barriers to the professional progression of STEM faculty. An analysis of service contributions among under-represented and well-represented faculty in STEM revealed parity in the service that was carried out by both groups, as well as the amount of compensation received for service contributions. The two groups reported to feel equally valued for their service contributions and rated these contributions as equally enjoyable and rewarding, though service contributions were experienced as more burdensome for faculty from under-represented groups compared to faculty from well-represented groups. Qualitative (focus groups) and quantitative (survey) data on faculty experiences with mentoring revealed a significant target for improvement and led us to devote concerted effort toward improving mentoring for Brooklyn College faculty. We endeavored to cultivate a culture of mentoring on the Brooklyn College campus by investigating best practices in mentoring and supporting a group of senior faculty to be trained at the Center for the Improvement of Mentored Experiences in Research (CIMER) so they could provide mentor training to others on the Brooklyn College campus. These trainers developed and deployed an intensive workshop that was delivered to 80 Brooklyn College faculty, staff, advisors, and administrators who are now CIMER-certified mentors. In addition, using data gathered from this project on professional progression, service equity, and mentoring experiences, we developed a proposal for a 5-year Strategic STEM Equity Plan and submitted it to the leadership of Brooklyn College for consideration.   

Intellectual Merit
Our Catalyst project has helped document obstacles to equity which include disparities in the pathway to promotion and tenure of science faculty and delayed professional advancement of women in STEM. We also used feedback from our faculty to guide our approach toward cultivating a culture of mentoring at the institution with the intention to better support the retention and satisfaction of our current faculty, and to improve our recruitment processes going forward. This culminated in a proposed 5-year strategic STEM equity plan that was submitted to the leadership of Brooklyn College.

Broader Impacts
The work carried out for this project has directly benefitted STEM faculty at Brooklyn College as well as faculty across departments in the four other schools at Brooklyn College (Humanities & Social Sciences; Business; Education; Visual Media & Performing Arts) through the propagation of mentor training and the cultivation of a culture of mentoring across the college. Moreover, out findings have the capacity to inform other primarily undergraduate, and minority serving institutions that equally value research and teaching in their efforts to improve equity for their faculty.


Last Modified: 12/29/2024
Modified by: Cheryl L Carmichael
